body.p: Endre Borza. I made this page to compile and present information about myself.
I built

ul.li: Rankless, an interactive visualization platform built on massive scholarly datasets
Machine learning and optimization software for logistics and football analytics
A collection of small, open-source tools that make my work easier

body.p: Since 2014 I have been working on the data side of a bunch of papers and one book, first I got some "thanks" in the acknowledgments, then I started to get credit as an author. There is a wide scope of topics here, from experimental economics, to park visitation patterns. The common thread is large, complex datasets that needed efficient processing, or creative analysis.

In 2015 I started teaching @ Rajk, and since then have taught courses in Programming and Algorithm Design, Applied Algorithm Design for Data Processing, and Statistical Methods for Causal Inference. I am also sometimes a guest instructor in machine learning and network science courses, both at rajk and at Corvinus University.

Turns out, I quite like teaching, and Rajk, with small classes and generally motivated students, was a great fit. I even got awarded the Permanent Professors of Rajk College title, which might be my favorite thing I've got as an accolade and the one thing I will brag about without anyone asking.
I use

ul.li: AI mostly from the command line, selectively but appreciatively

body.p: I like

Rankless was a great engineering challenge. I got to make a pipeline that processes over 3 billion citations among 300 million papers, and ends up with an app that responds to the most intricate breakdown requests practically instantly. To do this you really need to heavily optimize everything. A specialized Rust backend that has multi stage compilation that aligns to the shape and size of the data, plus a Svelte front-end with hand-rolled SVGs, no dependencies, as performant as it comes
It was Cesar's idea at ccl

2018-2021 I worked at Lidl as a data scientist. It was interesting, challenging, paid well, I learned a lot. It was a demanding environment with high employee turnover but still high productivity. After a few years, I got tired of not being able to show anything I've done to anybody, and not owning any of the fruits of my labor, so I took a massive pay cut and moved to academia.

Since I primarily work in academia since 2021, I did set up a gig where I can do consulting and development contract work still in the private sector. I find that it is nice to meet challenges that have market value and it's nice to get paid well. I had so far done some machine learning modeling and some highly convoluted data-collection. One of the drawbacks next to these great private sector benefits is that one can't really go into much detail.
Libraries to read/write parquet and csv in a parallel and efficient way in python. Entity coreference in both python and Julia, a Julia library for complexity plotting and estimation.

Apps like a browser extension to search for a scientific journal with one right-click (and then a left-click), a small dash app for creating quizzes for programming education, docker-based comparison tool of programming languages, running the same algorithm, with an interface for guessing results. Also a bunch of apps for rajk college, where I spent a wonderful 7 years and got to make tools for resolving preference-based course applications, uploading coursework, credit-card processing, teaching aids for presenting or evaluation, tinder-like quick evaluation tools for collective decision making and many failed others. I tried vanilla javascript with google sheets backends, raw PHP 5, and eventually Django. Most of them got the job done at the time, but the biggest benefit was getting my hands dirty, even before working together with a group of senior developers later.

These are mostly some sort of software that all become stale as versions move on. Simple tools, are fun because they can just be done, like an interactive article explaining quantum states and gates with hand-rolled 3d SVGs of Bloch-spheres, or a tool that helps my friend figure out how to cut a few pieces of wood to make a house-like bed for my godson.

Starting in 2018 at Lidl, we developed machine learning for demand prediction and algorithms to optimize delivery and distribution. We were quite successful, a lot of what we did got scaled up and is being used by Lidl widely. I also got to work with experienced developers and infra people plus technologies less frequently used in data science jobs like Kubernetes, Kafka, Elasticsearch, a lot of CI/CD and so on.
I quit mostly because I wanted more ownership of my work. It was ruthless, difficult and great
Worked on ML models and iterative algorithm design for evaluating team performance, player value and contract terms
Worked on a few papers, where in some cases complex football was used to draw parallels with other fields, or just analyzed the behaviour of referees
I sometimes create small pieces of analysis about football for myself, I rarely share it but here is one about the difficulty of partitions of Premier League fixtures.
FILL
Small libraries for parallel IO, data handling, and analysis support. - FILL

Open-source contributions are a great way to learn, and in many cases the best way to truly understand a tool is to make yourself be able to improve it. So for a while I did a bit of that but lost interest recently. I contributed to pandas, dask, pandas-profiling, the Julia language, fsspec, and dvc.
A project of mine that visualizes sql schemas with python even got a PR from a random person. I merged it, it was lovely, since I never really promote any of this.
In a team I built a central dataset and data-project standard/framework named datazimmer.

We also built tools around it like colassigner so that we don't use string literals with pandas so much, parquetranger to manage - save, load, extend - large datasets in partitioned parquet files, a task queue orchestrator atqo, raw data collection manager aswan - named after a dam, and some python package boilerplate branthebuilder so that we can start many others.
Contributions to academic research through data engineering and scalable analysis. - FILL
Teaching programming and data-heavy methods in small, motivated settings. - FILL

Started working in 2023 as a Research Data Engineer at ccl, a multidisciplinary lab started in Budapest by an EU grant. I help others publish papers involving complex data pipelines, but mostly I worked on rankless.org - a platform for the exploration of scholarly data. I managed to convince our director that I'd do the whole thing in Rust and Svelte without any large framework or ready-made tech like react, neo4j, or even anything SQL.
I also was responsible for setting up working environments for data heavy computations in research.

In 2021 I set up a small team called Social Science Computing Unit Budapest at the Centre for Economic and Regional Studies. We started to build a comprehensive data science toolset for scientific research. It slowed down a lot due to a range of issues, mostly around demand, but we did build a central dataset and data-project standard/framework and set up a lot of datasets for research around retail, weather, job-listings, chess, real-estate, football, news articles, interconnected wiki-pages, movies, etc. many of them periodically, automatically updating.

I like having everything being derived from code, easily reproducible. I try keeping everything I need that is necessary to setup a working environment for myself in one place here. It's not always perfectly up to date and comprehensive, but it reflects how I work.
Structured play that rewards systems thinking. - FILL
I started playing in 2020, and it turned out to be one of my primary recreational activities.

I find that running a D & D campaign is the ultimate test of any incorporeal inventory and note-taking system. You need to build a world, quickly retrieve information, very quickly input new information, and keep track of the knowledge of the world from the point of view of several PCs and NPCs. After trying a great number of options from the PKM and note-taking space, I settled for the time on Logseq, but am constantly building and improving my setup.
Play, like - FILL
I like writing short reviews from time to time about films, games, albums as it is great practice in expression. Film reviews are public on imdb, musicis going a lot slower
